CatDescriptText: Josephine Parker, housewife and church worker, Hill District and Marvin Anderson, record shop employee, Homewood, were part of Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 13, 1960, pg. 1 with question: "What are the most appealing and least appealing aspects of the Democratic Presidential candidate, Senator John F. Kennedy?"  Mrs. Parker's answer reads: "I'm not for Kennedy.  I'm afraid that we will not have freedom of worship - that there will be some kind of a dictatorship."  Mr. Anderson's answer reads: "I like the platform very much, and don't think that the fact that he is a Catholic will stop him from winning.  His least appeal is the fact that he has Lyndon Johnson as his running mate."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Josephine Parker wearing floral dress and dark hat with bow, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Marvin Anderson wearing short sleeved plaid shirt with light colored buttons and eyeglasses, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
